fastjson在1.2.68及之后的版本中引入了safeMode， 目前的版本是fastjson-1.2.61， 任然存在安全漏洞，我将fastjson 的版本直接替换为 1.2.9 后， 调度无法启动，不知该如何解决。

this pr make a new problem!!!
when you edit dag node , 
eg: 
1. update a sql and click ok(not save the dag)
2. switch tab to copy something
3. switch to ds dag edit tab
now open the node param ,found that the sql change is lost !

that means,i have to save the dag with any  small change!
that will make the dag version boom...

> this pr make a new problem!!!
> when you edit dag node ,
> eg:
> 
> 1. update a sql and click ok(not save the dag)
> 2. switch tab to copy something
> 3. switch to ds dag edit tab
>    now open the node param ,found that the sql change is lost !

Can you create a new issue?
This is the trade-off

> @geosmart @break60
> This is a problem caused by state synchronization in new tab. For state synchronization, we will refresh page in new opened page.
> If we don't do this, the issue **the task of a certain tab is changed, and the task of another tab will not be updated synchronously** referenced by @break60 will occur.

I know the visibilitychange can fix the sync problem
but the scenario of dag editor can not refresh to make the data loss
the dag design is usually need to switch tab ,eg. copy a sql snippet

the designing dag data will loss when:
1. switch browser to another app
2. switch browser tab

this means: 
you must design a complex dag without refer anything, that's impossibe!
or you have to save the uncomplete dag version(it's a garbage dag version, not real working when scheduled)
This merged pr is based on `visibilitychange `
Maybe I filter some scenarios to resolve this issue, so I will fix it.

visibility change is a good feature, if you add some filter may be better :
1. some scenario no need to refresh: **create,update**
2. some scenario need to refresh: **detail,list**

@yefei-ddyw

Priority of queue: queue from `other args` > user queue > tenant queue

Flink: 1.3.x has bug about queue, so that the job will be submitted to the `default` queue regardless of the existing user or tenant queue. The latest dev branch has fixed it.
Spark: No problem
MR: No problem

Could this information help you explain the current problem?

@yefei-ddyw @xingchun-chen

User | Tenant | User Queue   (Submitted) | Tenant Queue   (Ignored) | Yarn Queue   (Actual)
-- | -- | -- | -- | --
1 | ddyw | root.hdfs.flink | root.hdfs.mapreduce | root.hdfs.ddyw
2 | dd011 | root.hdfs.mapreduce | root.hdfs.spark | root.hdfs.dd011
3 | ddyw1 | root.hdfs.spark | root.hdfs.flink | root.hdfs.ddyw1

Both user queue and tenant queue are inconsistent.

I guess the reason is as follows:

The tenant ddyw submits a job with user queue `root.hdfs.flink`, not the tenant queue `root.hdfs.mapreduce`, so that `root.hdfs.flink` doesn't take effect. It may be caused by queue permissions.

And then, the job doesn't meet rule 1 in Dynamic Resource Pool Configuration, so the second rule takes effect by using `root..[username]` with middle pool name `hdfs`.

In summary, the job submitted by the tenant ddyw will use `root.hdfs.ddyw` queue in yarn.
